topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53e3f8ce6368721dac4c0000#post_53e3f8ce6368721dac4c0000
Here's something surprising; the biggest factor effecting crime though is . . . drum roll please. *drumroll.sfx* The economic standing of the individual.  What I mean by this is that the higher the economic standing of a individual the more likely they are to commit non-violent crimes and more likely they are to commit crimes like identity theft or some such.  In other words it's far less likely for a millionaire to rob a gas station at gunpoint.

In other words for all sides if you want to reduce violent crimes theoretically your best shot at this would be promote higher living standards through economic means.

topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53e3fb356368722a6d0a0000#post_53e3fb356368722a6d0a0000
Eh; I kind of agree and kind of disagree.

I like capitalism because capitalist countries have higher standard of living, but on the other hand letting the economy just go without any regulation or oversight is a bad idea cause reckless speculation causes economic busts.

What I mean by this is that yes capitalism is good, but not for every industry and not 100% of the time.  Sometimes you do need oversight and sometimes you do need to use subsidies.  *SOMETIMES*  What I mean by this is for a company that is a nuclear energy company they need some huge fucking regulations cause the last time the USA was lack with safety regulation three mile island happened.  Other times lax oversight is good.  It's really on a case by case basis of what is the industry and whether or not they are economically unstable.  Economically unstable sectors and sectors that have very real dangers to human risk need far more regulation in general.

Sometimes subsidies and bail outs are good and sometime they're bad.  The wall street bail out made me rage cause yes they needed a bail out, but they didn't need that hundred billion dollars; they only needed a couple hundred million dollars; there's a massive difference between a hundred billion dollars and a hundred million dollars.  You should have heard how many profanities I said when I found out they were getting a hundred billion dollars.  If I had a swear jar I could have bought a new car.  A example of a good subsidy is solar roadways; right now the company developing this has received subsidies to help the company with their research and thanks to the research being done chances are we'll have a cheap energy source in the next decade.  A example of a bad subsidy is when a monopoly receives a subsidy.

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53e3fe256368722a26840000#post_53e3fe256368722a26840000
I have to disagree, but largely I think the issue is misframed.

Iceland did not bail out its banks. Iceland is doing well now.
Which is why Matt Damon's documentary was dumb, but well intentioned.

Iceland did what the market said: let them fail.

Ultimately the short term disruption was better than long term cronyism.

The US is actually not a particularly capitalist country. Corporatism is more common.

As for energy subsidies, Solyndra has been enough of a boondoggle to be cautious about them.

But what I am getting at is many of the societal ills ascribed to capitalism are not remotely capitalist in nature beyond involving some company.

Nearly every economic bubble and bust was caused by the government altering the money supply making speculation artificially profitable.

And while market failures have occurred in the past, using the recession from the roaring twenties that predated the Depression, the economy bounced back quickly.
New research, on the other hand, shows that the New Deal probably made the Depression last longer
 http://mises.org/freemarket_detail.aspx?control=515
^ they have other articles on the subject.

Ultimately, I take a socialist approach on issues the government is already involved in. As socialism does make economic sense at times. For example, I would prefer a completely socialist healthcare system to either the old US system or Obamacare. And it can make moral sense
topics.author: 4fe16df67f123b13e400003f

topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53e4014a63687241e6cf0000#post_53e4014a63687241e6cf0000
*look at clock
Oh crap; I'm late.

I'll make it short: I agree partially.  Also I totally agree on the corporatism part.

The problem with the USA right now and why the not having any bail would have been bad is that the banks have the USA at metaphorical gunpoint.  Also as for bail outs effects on economic recoveries, partially agree; if the bail out wasn't so large the economy would have recovered faster because all that money didn't go to the economy it just got pocketed instead.  My problem with the bail out was of how much it was for.  If they were given just what they actually needed then it would have been fine, but all that money instead got pocketed.  It's like giving a kid a cake before dinner to try to make them eat dinner; they're just going to eat the cake and want more cake instead of eating diner.  To use a analogy I would have just gave them some bananas with their dinner instead.  The problem with banks right now is that they're spoiled.  If they throw enough of a fit they'll get a cake instead of getting a healthy dinner.


As for socialism; yeah socialism is often good in some sectors but not in others.  With health care I totally agree.

"@Randomosaur":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53e4056e63687245a9910000#post_53e4056e63687245a9910000
This might be relevant to you interests. They're from Fallout.
!http://img3.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20110511012723/fallout/images/thumb/e/e6/Enclave_deathclaw.png/500px-Enclave_deathclaw.png!
!http://images3.wikia.nocookie.net/__cb20110511010936/fallout/images/thumb/f/fe/Deathclawmother.png/497px-Deathclawmother.png!
!http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-EYTCEcgI6_A/TkYYsQknaXI/AAAAAAAAAGs/eb28uQ8hXY4/s1600/Deathclaw.png!

They're called Deathclaws. Bioengineered mutant Jackson's chameleons mixed with the DNA of various other species.
The deathclaws were originally created before the Great War by the government to replace humans during close-combat search-and-destroy missions. They were derived from mixed animal stock and then refined by the Master, using genetic manipulation. The resulting creature is almost unbelievably fast and powerful.

topics.body:
"@Randomosaur":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53e424f26368720f20740100#post_53e424f26368720f20740100
I'm going to assume you're joking and give a more general answer.

Even works set entirely in the real world with absolutely no fantastical elements rely on a certain amount of implausible coincidence, action and motivation. Note that implausible is not the same as impossible.
